cluster_relations.rel_desc: These studies quantify what fraction of communication is conveyed via body language.

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: Proportion of communication conveyed via body language

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The studies estimate the percentage of communication that is transmitted via body language.

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: Proportion of communication attributed to body language

remarks: Numeric proportion is also stored as a node property; duplicated here as a relation qualifier.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Research on nonverbal communication examines the role and magnitude of nonverbal cues in communication.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: ResearchOutcome: nonverbal cues are a significant portion of communication

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The broader body of research on nonverbal communication includes the specific studies that estimate body language's share of communication.
remarks: Slight ambiguity whether 'research' refers broadly to the same set of studies.

args.canonical_rel_desc: The subject study quantitatively measures what fraction or proportion of the object phenomenon is attributable to a specified component or channel.
args.justification: This relation links specific studies to the overall communication process they quantify in terms of proportion conveyed via body language; the key predicate is that the study measures a fraction of the communication.

args.canonical_rel_desc: The subject study provides a quantitative estimate of how much the object contributes to a broader process or outcome, usually expressed as a proportion or percentage.
args.justification: Here the studies quantitatively estimate the contribution of body language itself, rather than of the overall communication process; a separate but closely related predicate clarifies that the object is the contributing factor.

Both relations describe studies that provide quantitative (percentage/proportion) characterizations of aspects of communication, differing only in what is being quantified; they naturally belong to a shared class of quantitative characterization/measurement links.
In both cases, the core semantic dimension is measurement/quantification (estimating proportions and contributions), not causation or composition per se.

args.canonical_rel_desc: The subject research activity examines, studies, or explores the properties, role, or behavior of the object.
args.justification: The relation explicitly describes research on nonverbal communication examining nonverbal cues; the standard research predicate 'investigates' captures this focus clearly and is reusable.
This relates a research activity to its substantive focus (nonverbal cues), which is best modeled as a class of research-focus or topic relations.
The subject (research activity) is an agentive process acting on or directed toward the object (nonverbal cues), so an agency-oriented group is appropriate.

args.canonical_rel_desc: The subject research activity or program generates the object research outputs, such as specific studies, papers, or findings.
args.justification: The description states that the broader body of research includes or gives rise to the specific studies estimating body language's share of communication; modeling this as research producing research outputs makes the provenance explicit.
args.remark: If later schema prefers a more generic provenance predicate, this can be normalized to a shared production/provenance canonical relation.

args.justification: This relation connects a research activity to the concrete studies it yields, fitting a class that captures research-to-output or project-to-product relations.
The semantics involve a generative causal link where the research activity leads to (produces) specific studies; this aligns best with a causality-oriented group.
